segments.text: One of the strong supporters of the Colonel's Revolt.
Not so much the Colonel's Revolt, but of what we were trying to do.
The objective, which was to build an army instead of allowing it to be destroyed.
Well, General Gavin, James M. Gavin, who was Chief of Research and Development and later Chief of Army Operations and Plans,
And I was very close to General Gavin.
I think he was a wonderful man.
You know, he was a major general when he was about 30 years old, 31 years old.
Commanded 82nd Division, I guess, 82nd Airborne.
He was one of the early airborne types.
I was involved in Fort Benning in the early days and glider training on the 4X5 type.
I was in the second armored division and didn't go to that side of the thing because this armored thing was so fascinating to me, the mechanization.
As you know, our armored divisions were patterned after the German Panzer divisions.
The first that we had in our country, the first and the second.
Mr. Wilson finally cut him off from the press, cut him off from visiting Congress, cut him off from answering letters to the Congress, and that sort of thing.
And all the letters that came to him from the Congress where we were mustering support to get an army, to build an army of the future.
He was not permitted to answer, and I would go by each morning and pick up his letters and answer them myself, show him the answers, and sign them off myself back to the Congress.
So that was a way around him violating an edict from the White House through the Secretary of Defense.
We had a— What specifics?
What specific proposals did you put forth to the congressman?
We know what Wilson's trying to do.
He's trying to cut the size of conventional forces and build a nuclear force and the so-called more bang for the buck idea.
One specific one was Jupiter C. Missile.
I wanted, and General Gavin wanted to go ahead and fire in September the 26th
1956, and to place in orbit a satellite.
And we were ready to do it, had the capability to do it.
We'd had some failures with the Navy Vanguard system, but Jupiter C, which later was Redstone Missile,
We had a major general, Maderas, down there, a real sharp ordnance major general.
And we know where we were going.
We needed about $10 million in order to launch.
Eisenhower and Wilson turned us down.
We got the money in the program.
They wouldn't spend it.

next year following the Sputnik was fired and made us look like a bunch of asses and uh so this is you must have got the money after Sputnik oh yes got it then sure but you see what you see what I'm talking about and I'd like history to know this and and uh another thing uh they uh Wilson and Eisenhower turned down us having
tactical nuclear weapons along with Admiral Radford the chairman of the Joint Chiefs.

So Senator Scoop Jackson who is a magnificent individual and a knowing man and who believes in the defense of the free world in the United States he was chairman of the Joint he was chairman of the subcommittee
for military application on the Joint Committee on Atomic Energy.
It was a joint committee in those days between the House and the Senate.
Chet Holifield was the chairman, as I recall.
And this is going back some 30 years, you know, almost.
And...
Senator Jackson was chairman of the military application subcommittee.
General Gavin sent me over and said, we cannot get Radford or the president or Wilson to prove off on these artillery projectiles, 155 and 8-inch.
They just won't do it.
With tactical nuclear weapons.
He said, what can you do?
I said, well, let's get it done.
So I go over and I talk to important members of the House Armed Services, Senate Armed Services, and in a matter of a few days, we get a request from
Senator Jackson to brief him on our requirements, and we go.
General Gavin and I and one other nuclear specialist in the operating business.
And we get that approved over the heads of the President and the Secretary of Defense and the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs.
That was a part at that time of the whole thing of trying to save an army and make it viable and capable of defending this country.
Give me another specific.
Was the airborne part of it another specific?
Another one was helicopters.
Another one was tactical fighters.
Another one was tactical airlift.
All of those.
Better munitions.
Which ones did you succeed on, and which ones couldn't you get through Congress?
I guess we eventually got them all.
Eventually got them all.
The Colonel's Revolt, then, was a heavy lobbying effort behind the administration.
Both.
Within the public, within the industry, and within the Congress.
Okay, we talked a little bit about Congress.
How about industry?
What did you do as far as that?
Industry?
We had General Motors and other corporations that were deeply involved in lightening up equipment and making helicopters, looking at helicopter capability.
We'd had some experience with helicopters in Korea and we were looking at larger units other than just a helicopter company and lighter weight weapons.
The M-16 was one.

lightweight machine gun was one of them a airborne artillery we already had but new projectiles like ICM improved conventional munitions little things everybody's complaining about over in Israel right here there's one right there you put 500 of those in a cluster bomblet that's a
That's a bomblet right there.
Now look at the other end of it and you'll see it's a shaped charge.
So that's the improved conventional munition.
We say dual purpose.
That'll burn a hole through the top of a lightweight vehicle.
It'll also hit the ground and explode and throw fragments for 30 meters.
And when you get a canister of 500 of those dumped in a
about six football fields that don't let many people get away, you see.
So that's a cluster bomb like CBU, that was one of the ideas we had.
We have that in the artillery projectile now.
There's some more than a couple hundred in the eight inch and there's something less than a hundred in the 155 round.
That's the new munition, it's very effective for us.
But you understand the shape-charge effect?
No.
You see this?
You see this?
The explosive is...
This is all explosive, but it's a shape-charge.
This fuse starts it burning from the back end of that place there, you see?
And it fires a hot...
This...
cone shape here reverse cone here that hits that like that this little fuse in here starts this burning and it puts out a a 900 degree centigrade or more uh stream of fire that
burns a hole through this light armor here about the size of my finger.
But on the other side, the spalling will be an area about this big of hot molten metal that destroys personnel inside the vehicle.
But that's what we call a shaped charge, where the fire starting here and the intensity starts back here.
This causes
a sharp burning flame of about the size of my little finger here to concentrate on that particular point, burning a hole through and causing spalling on the inside.
So basically the cluster bomb then can go, the first thing it does is penetrate into the vehicle.
Into a light, thin-skinned vehicle, a light armored vehicle.
Into a light, like a personnel carrier or something like that?
And then once it gets inside it has,
Well, what it does is molten metal from that is burned away.
Now, it will also hit the ground and explode.
It has an explosive effect also.
Fragments.
This fragment is from here.
This breaks away as fragmentation.
That cone there burns through things.
I see.
So that's dual purpose.
Dual purpose.
We call it DPICM, Improved Conventional Munition.
We used it in Vietnam.
Yeah, I know we used the clusters in Vietnam.
Another one we were after was...
Fuel bombs, let's see if I can give you, CBU-55 was a fuel bomb of three canisters of 60 pounds each with a small parachute on it.

has a delayed fuse it hits the ground explodes allows out this say propane and uh with a delayed fuse this being gas being heavier and airy it goes down in the holes and in the tunnels and then explodes a tremendous weapon it'll clear each one of those 60 pound canisters will clear uh maybe uh
fifty meter diameter of all the brush and everything else, plus kills everything down in the holes in that area in which it was.
It's the only system we have that really will get down in a hole or a cave and get a fella out.
Were they used in Vietnam?
Yes.
I think they would have been useful there.
Well, they were very, very useful, and Mr. Carter cut them out and wouldn't let the Israelis have them.
I thought the Israelis ought to go ahead and make them themselves.
They're not that difficult to make.
Now let's talk a little bit about how you manipulated industry, Congress, and other people.
Did you have sort of a public relations campaign?
One fellow was responsible with the press.
Oh, really?
One of the colonels?
Yes.
One of them carried the press and leaked to them information that was counter to the big bang for the buck.
Yeah, counter to the administration's view.
In other words, the administration is—
is destroying the conventional capability of our armed forces.
Apparently little consideration being given to the fact that conventional wars of limited types and for limited duration which impact on our national security cannot be

dealt with this philosophy and this sort of strategy and therefore Congress and the American people ought to know the truth on what's happening and that sort of stuff and that continuous approach in that direction.
And we had a top secret document somehow got leaked out by a
colonel that was responsible for that aspect of it.
What did that document deal with?
What was the basic topic?
I think it dealt primarily with the organization of the five colonels and then it hit the press.
About the same time
The authorization bill had, was being debated on the floor, which was tremendously different from that in which the administration had submitted.
Mr. Eisenhower said root out the, those people that asked Wilson to
investigate and find out who they are, and Wilson said there's a bunch of eager beavers gnawing on the wrong tree.
And, uh, I had a little fire, I guess, in the Pentagon, and that took care of that.
We were all investigated.
That took care of the documents.
Yeah, it took care of all the documents.
We were investigated.
by direction of Mr. Wilson.
I had already been selected for the Army War College and that list was out.
There was a reconsideration of the whole list and as I recall one colonel went to command and all the others went to
war colleges, either the National War College or the Army War College.
Investigations continued while we were there.
I was accused of passing top secret documents to the Congress and the investigator that investigated me, I thought he was kind of a foolish chap.
He was doing his job,
He thought that it was really bad that I was passing top secret documents to the Congress.
Well, did you admit that?
Oh yes, I admitted it.
I said, oh yes, I certainly did.
He said, well, who'd you send them to?
I said, members of the Senate Armed Services Committee, House Armed Services Committee, Senate Appropriations Committee, House Appropriations Committee,

senate foreign relations committee house foreign affairs committee and i said all of those people are cleared for top secret and even security clearance is higher than yours colonel and i said let's be sure that we get this on the record here and i'm surprised that you didn't know or whoever put you up to this didn't know that members of congress many of them carry them higher security clearances and
than some members of the Armed Forces.
I got off a clean bill of health.
My friend who was also at the Army War College with me, who's not living now, Don Ewell, Y-U-E-L-L, class of 39 from West Point,
was the only one as far as I know that received any punishment at all and his was administrative reprimand because he's the one that the top secret document accidentally got away from.
To the press?
To the press, yeah.
So that ended a story in my life except while at the War College I continued to fight
for and made speech after speech on the floor to all the students about the pentamic division, which was a destruction of our army capability.
I continue to do that.
And I've continued to work toward what we need, and I'm doing it right today.
I guess I'll always.
So you said that before that you were close here to a court-martial.
Is that as close as you came?
That's as close as I ever came.
Ms. Hollingsworth thought that her objective in life, I think, was to do whatever she could to prevent me from being another Billy Mitchell.
And that never entered my mind.
It never entered my mind that I was going to be court-martialed for what I was doing, because I believed in what I was doing.
I believed in the Army, I believed in our country, and I'm honest.
And if you're honest, you don't have to, and you speak the truth,
from what you know to be the truth, and you speak not otherwise, then you never have to worry about tomorrow.
You don't have to worry about what you said today.
You never have to do that.
You don't have to have a long memory.
Yes, but honesty is one thing, and politics is something entirely different at times.
That's true.
And you're dealing now, and not in the military sphere—
but you're dealing in a political sphere and the politicians also think that they're honest, they just have a different view of the world in this particular case.

So weren't you ever fearful that the politicians, the president, the secretary of defense, your civilian authorities, weren't you fearful that you were going to jeopardize your career because you were taking an opposite view and taking it so stridently?
I guess I didn't give that very much consideration as I look back on it.
I still had a great belief in man regardless of whether he was a politician or whether he was a commoner on a day laborer or a dock worker.
I had a great belief in God

and that he had made a determination somewhere along the line that I'd do certain things and I had witnessed his protection of me and safeguarding of me in some very serious conflict and battle and some very serious warnings that he had given me in which I accepted and which I would never have been here if I had not
If he had not signaled me to certain dangers, I'm talking about the great master of all of us.

So I'm a real strong believer, and when I believe in what I'm trying to do, I've never allowed anything to interfere with it because I always trust in him signaling me and pulling me out before I step over the side of the mountain.
Obviously some of your superiors thought you were doing the right thing and supported you, otherwise you wouldn't have been promoted at that time to full colonel.
That's right, sir.
That's true.
Very true.
And how can you account for being promoted?
I mean obviously you have an outstanding record, but you're in a situation here which might be damaging to your career.
Who do you think it was that wanted you to become a, get a promotion?
Well, I think General Ridgway, and I think General Taylor.

In fact, when I left to go to War College, I went in to see General Taylor to tell him goodbye, and he said to me, he said, you've had some trying times, and said you have done an outstanding job, and I want you to take this photograph here,
that I've autographed for you and he said, I just want you to know that I would never make you a general officer unless you've done what you've done.
That's what he said.
And I thought to myself, that's a hell of a compliment from a hell of a great man.
So, I went off to War College and continued to be controversial there amongst the students, but a leader amongst the students.
We had committees where you study
to build a national strategy.
That was very helpful to me in building a new strategy in Korea, a new strategy in Pakistan, and also for him, and also for working certain programs when I was Deputy Secretary of Defense.
Two-track system in high school, I worked with HEW on that.
The two-year trade schools in South Carolina have been a great supporter of that.
You've got to understand that some people are suited for academics, but most of us are not.
I think maybe, generally speaking, we've had too damn many people go to college and not enough learn the trade.
We got a lot of people with PhDs but not of our experience.

The Vietnam conflict fostered a hide from the war by going to get a baccalaureate degree and graduate in June and start in September on a master's degree and when you finish that one go the next year to a PhD and you
In my view, that sort of thing has not contributed one goddamn thing to our society.
And that's the reason why I find some PhDs today out working as day laborers and can't get a job.
And my view of education is that you get a, if you're academically inclined to make a contribution to our society,

you get a baccalaureate degree and then you go get some experience in that and find out where is it you can best make a contribution and then go back and get a higher degree in the area in which you like and you can make a contribution and then after you've gone out and had a look at that and made some mistakes and said well I made a mistake here or there but here's where I can do
then you can go ahead after experience and become a Ph.D. and really make a contribution to our country.
And if you can't, then God damn it, you haven't done anything but fool yourself and the American people.
You see?
I got funny ideas about this, but that's the way it is.
I don't think it's the damn funny.
So you were a leader there at the War College.
Oh, yeah.
I had...
Many committees.
I chaired many committees.
One committee was, I chaired a committee to study the Iranian, Turkestan, Tashkent, Armenian, Black Sea area, Gaspain Sea area, that part of the world.
As a matter of fact,
For six weeks I was a red army commander, a field marshal of the total red army to take the Mediterranean.
And opposing forces was another fellow.
And you had to play it as it is today with the top secret intelligence of both sides.
And I beat the hell out of Americans.
And then, for six weeks, I became the American commander to come up with what is needed in order to avoid that.
Then that becomes a part of a kind of a detailed, worked out, colonel level Air Force, Army, Navy students who are there.
strategy for defense of the Persian Gulf against the Soviets.
Because of your interest in that area, is that why they sent you to Pakistan right after your completion of the course?
I think so, I think so.
So from 1957 then until 1959 you were the chief of the U.S. Army.
element of the MAG group in Pakistan.
Now, of course at this time, India is having problems with Pakistan.
Right.
We were trying to play a balancing act here, weren't we, as far as our policy is concerned?
Yes.
That must have put you in a pretty tough spot.
Put me in a hell of a tough spot.
As a matter of fact,
To answer General Iyub's question, who was a commander-in-chief and lived at Rawalpindi, and I lived in the same general area, maybe half a mile away.
What was his name?
Iyub Khan, A-Y-U-B-K-H-A-N.
He was a general, commander-in-chief of the armed forces, later president.
And I got deeply involved in that, his becoming president.
while I was there.
He became president, yes, I will tell you.
But my mission was one of training about five or six divisions of the Pakistani Army and equipping those with American equipment.
And some of the questions that you encountered from
General Iyub later President Iyub was how can you deny me the use of your military aid equipment in the Azad Kashmir border area where we have a United Nations ceasefire team between the Indians.
How can you deny me the use
of your aid equipment up there machine guns rifles mortars tanks trucks and that sort of thing while at the same time you give the Indians 300 million grant aid and they go by
106-millimeter recoilless rifles from you and Jaguar fighter planes from the British and bring them up here and use them against me.
And said, you've been up there, and I'll point them out to you, your U.S. equipment.
I said, General, are you...
I'm a military man and a soldier, as you are.
I said, I can't answer that question.
I said, that's a question that should be asked by your prime minister of our president.
He said, they're politicians and they won't ask each other questions like that.
And he said, that's what's wrong with, and that's what's part of the problem here in this country.

He said, your government gives my government wheat, and there's ship load after ship load of wheat stacked in the harbor, rotting in Karachi, and my government doesn't have sense enough or the capability
to get the weed out to our tribal people and the villagers here who have sore bellies because they're not getting enough to eat.
Yet the weed is rotting down there.
And he said, why does your government do that?
Why does your government gloat over what support you're giving us here beyond our capability to even manage?
and you deny me in an area where I need things, military, you've limited me to very little.
Said, are you, said, we have declared ourselves as friends of the United States, but are you really my friend?
We're your friend, but are you really my friend?
Because here's what you're doing to us.
Those questions are very difficult, very hard to,
to explain and you put your American foreign policies, put honest people out at the colonel and general level in a hell of a position.
So you get on with
or trying to support your government, or you quit and get out.
So, I think most of the military feels that they've got something to contribute.
Kind of swallow hard and go ahead and do the best they can under the circumstances.
Did you bring the Pakistani divisions?
Did you bring them up to par?

I brought the Pakistani divisions up to par except in one area, which is a crucial area in that part of the world amongst all of the peoples in the Middle East, including all the Arab nations, including the Iranians, Pakistanis, most all of the people in that area.
of the world.
And that is that they do not understand this business of logistics support and the management of the things that's necessary in order to keep a fighting force in being and sustainable during combat.
And that's

ammunition and this was brought out very clearly against a war which occurred after I left there where in the Brits I mean where in the Indians and Pakistan went at it over Kashmir area and Pakistani tank battalions were just eating up the Indians driving them back
until they ran out of fuel and ran out of ammunition, at which point in time they got out of their tanks, left them, and walked back.
They cited recorded instances of that.
Those soldiers came out of the villages
ninety percent of them out of the villages.
We're in, they've been there eighteen years with a wooden plow and bullocks.
There's not much logistic support there for that.
And you don't change people overnight.
Okay?
Now tell me about the episode of helping the general and your role in that.
After I'd been there some time, well, I hadn't been there very long until I gained his confidence and he certainly gained mine.
I thought he was one of the most magnificent men I had ever met in my life.
Why do you say that?
Well, he was the most balanced man.
He was a British sand hearse trained officer.
He commanded, he was the first commander of a British battalion during World War II in India.
Normally British units, those commands are all Brit officers

second in command is an Indian, or a Pakistani, or a Gurkha, or whoever it might be, Ethiopia, an Egyptian, something like that, but all those commands, that's the Brits, they had saved those positions, except Iyub, I think, was the first one that really was a commander of a battalion.
And he's just one brilliant man, and was commander in chief, and
had a great personality.
He loved to shoot, loved to hunt, and the hunting was great in the Himalayas, bird shooting.
He was a good horseman, although he didn't play polo, he was a good horseman.
He wanted me to play golf with him, which I did.
We'd go shooting together, Miss Hollingsworth and Begum Ayoub,
who was still in Perda, but Mrs. Ayoub and Mrs. Hollingsworth.
And the daughters were very close to Mrs. Hollingsworth.
I went by to visit the daughter and the son-in-law.
The son-in-law was a Wally of Swat, the governor of Swat State.
And so, we were kind of a close family.
And Ayoub's son knew
He was in the military and we were very close as a matter of fact.
He called one day, an aide called one day.
We worked from 7 o'clock in the morning until 12 o'clock and the temperatures were such that you stayed in the rest of the day.
I went about other things where you were not subject to the stress and the heat.
None of the facilities were air conditioned were they?
No, none.
I had a call about one o'clock, and it was General Ayoub's aide, and he said, General Ayoub would like to speak to you, and I said, yes sir.
He said, Holly, he said, I didn't get a chance to see you this morning, he said.
Could I come over now?"
And I said, yes, sir, General, you please do.
I'm here at home.
On the veranda, Miss Hollingsworth and Mrs. O'Brien, Captain O'Brien's wife was one of my ordnance officers out of my team of about 12 officers.
We're sitting on the veranda and our chocodile

who was a guard, opened the gate and in came the big black Cadillac limousine and General Ayoub got out and greeted the ladies and myself and I knew he wanted to see me so I said, well, General Ayoub, since I didn't get a chance to see you this morning,
Maybe we could excuse ourselves and present the ladies here and go back to one of the drawing rooms, of which there was three in my quarters.
He said, oh yes, I'd love to.
I'd love to do that.
So we go back.
I said, sir, it's two o'clock.
Would you like a whiskey?
He said, yes, I believe I would.
So we had a whiskey.
It was scotch with water and no ice.
British style.
So the bear came in, and Ibram was a bear.
He brought in a drink, and he said, well, said, Holly, I might as well get on with it.
I said, yes, sir.
He said, did you ever think about taking over a country?
I said, uh,
No, sir, not really, but I said I've studied all the principles involved and it's been applied by other governments and throughout a large share of history.
And I know key principles that's involved in taking over the country and what you have to do.
He said, well, my government is trying to run an advanced state of democracy in order to satisfy your foreign policy requirements so we can get aid for our people.
